awd_titl_txt: FRG: Collaborative Research: Moduli Spaces, Birational Geometry, and Stability Conditions
awd_abstract_narration:
Many processes in life, ranging from credit card transactions to the growth of a sunflower, are modeled by systems of polynomial equations. Algebraic geometry studies solutions of such systems. A major feature of these systems is that they vary in families by varying the coefficients of the polynomials. Some equations in the family are easier to solve, and properties of more complicated systems can be deduced from the solutions of the simpler systems. The investigators study the geometry of certain spaces defined by polynomial equations that are ubiquitous in mathematics and physics, called moduli spaces of vector bundles. They compute geometric invariants of these spaces by relating them to simpler spaces using a recent breakthrough called Bridgeland stability. The investigators are also dedicated to training the next generation of U.S. scientists and researchers. In this project, they will train undergraduate, graduate, and postdoctoral researchers to use the new technique of Bridgeland stability. The Focused Research Group grant will support these young researchers to visit and collaborate with several senior researchers and to attend conferences and workshops on the topic. The investigators will also organize two large conferences and four workshops to help attract young talent to the area.

Moduli spaces of vector bundles are fundamental objects in algebraic geometry, with applications to commutative algebra, representation theory, combinatorics, and mathematical physics. In the last five years, Bridgeland stability conditions have revolutionized the understanding of moduli spaces of vector bundles on surfaces. They have allowed the computation of the ample and effective cones of divisors on these moduli spaces and led to the solution of longstanding problems such as the existence of Lagrangian fibrations on certain hyperkähler manifolds of K3 type and the higher rank interpolation problem for general sheaves on the plane. It is timely to apply these new techniques to central problems in the geometry of moduli spaces of vector bundles on surfaces and threefolds. This Focused Research Group project centers on three lines of inquiry:
(1) Prove cohomology vanishing results using Bridgeland stability and consequently construct Ulrich bundles on surfaces and threefolds and effective Brill-Noether divisors on moduli spaces of vector bundles on surfaces. Give applications to Le Potier's Strange Duality Conjecture.
(2) Determine when special bundles, such as Lazarsfeld-Mukai bundles or null-correlation bundles on surfaces and threefolds, are Bridgeland stable. Apply the stability to classical problems on syzygies and Koszul cohomology.
(3) Study the birational geometry of moduli spaces of Bridgeland stable objects via wall-crossing.  
The investigators plan to train ten undergraduates, ten graduate students, and seven postdoctoral associates through research involvement in the project.

por.por_cntn:
This project investigated some moduli spaces associated to Fano threefolds using a novel tool borrowed from string theory. 

There are two central classification problems in complex algebraic geometry. One of them is the classification of the projective manifolds themselves, which are defined by algebraic relations among complex variables. It can be really difficult to distinguish manifolds from each other, i.e. to decide that two complex projective manifolds are not the same manifold whose apparent differences are just a complicated change of variables. One way of doing this is to associate a moduli space (the other classification problem) to each manifold and detect the differences among the manifolds from the different geometric properties of the moduli spaces. A classical example of this is the moduli space of line bundles (the Jacobian) on a Riemann surface (a complex manifold of dimension one). In that case, two Riemann surfaces are seen to be distinct if they are either topologically distinct (different genus) or, while topologically the same, the theta divisors of their Jacobians have differing singularities. This is known as the Torelli theorem for Riemann surfaces and it has analogues in higher dimensions.

String theorists and algebraists provided us with another way to view complex projective manifolds, through the derived categories of chains of vector bundles on the manifold. The derived category was discovered by Maxim Kontsevich to be a powerful way to mathematically account for the mysterious property of ``mirror symmetry'' when applied to Calabi-Yau manifolds (higher dimensional analogues of elliptic curves). But in a series of important papers from the Russian school, especially Alexander Kuznetsov, the derived category of a Fano manifold (a positively curved complex manifold) decomposes into a discrete part and a continuous part, which is dubbed the "Kuznetsov kernel." This kernel resembles the derived category of a (possibly fractional dimensional) Calabi-Yau manifold and it is a very interesting classification problem to determine how much of information about the Fano manifold is captured by this kernel. 

Our project studied six families of Fano manifolds in dimension three with a view towards solving the Torelli problem, constructing moduli spaces akin to the Jacobian of a Riemann surface associated only to the kernel of their derived categories, and then recovering the manifolds via a Torelli theorem. Our tool was the stability conditions borrowed from string theory (inspired by mirror symmetry) as mathematically presented by Tom Bridgeland. In five of the cases, we got a complete, very satisfactory, answer. In a suitable sense, the Fano manifold was itself visible inside the moduli space, and therefore determined by the kernel. 

This work formed a significant part of the PhD dissertations of five graduate students: Huachen Chen and Franco Rota (2019), Matteo Altavilla and Dapeng Mu (2020) and Marin Petkovic (2022). We are very grateful for the support of this NSF FRG grant in allowing us to focus our team through student release time and also to disseminate our results through the workshops funded by the grant.
